text: - Hi, I'm Kevin Lewis.
Welcome back to our masterclass
on data governance from AWS.
And so now I'd like to talk

about sustaining the
data governance program
and improving it over time.
And the way we wanna do that
is to embed data governance
into the operating model of the company.

So we can talk about the
processes and procedures
as it relates to data governance itself,
but I think it's even more important

to talk about how we
institutionalize data governance

by making it a part of the
fabric of the organization.
So we talked earlier about, of course,
you know, targeting business initiatives
and aligning our data governance program
to those initiatives.
And that's all, you know, well and good,
and it works very, very well,
but how do we keep that going over time?
Okay, so when we talk about aligning
to business initiatives,
a lot of times you have to find them,
you have to jostle schedules,

you have to figure out how
to convince the leaders

of those programs that you're
there to help their program.
And I call it,

it's like running alongside a
moving train and jumping on,

because these things
are already in motion,

and you've got to take your
data governance program
and align it to those initiatives
that are already in motion.

And at the beginning of a
data governance program,
there's really no choice.
You have to do it that way.

But rather than jumping
onto a moving train,
how can we catch the train
at the station like a normal person?
And so let's talk about how we do that.
And the way to do that is to look

for some very specific processes
within your organization
that you can attach data governance to

to make it a part of the
fabric of the organization.

So if we talk about aligning
to business initiatives,

well, where do those business
initiatives come from?
Where are they first created?
And they're typically created

through some kind of
strategic planning process.

So the company and different
departments and business units

within the organization
typically have some kind
of strategic planning process where,
you know executives will get together.
They'll think about, you know,

what are the initiatives we
wanna do for the coming year
or over the next three years?
And ideally you would have someone,
like a chief data officer,

participating directly in that
strategic planning activity.

So again, this is where
we link data governance,
not only to data strategy,

but through data strategy to
the rest of the enterprise.
And so the chief data officer
within that strategic planning process
is basically gonna do a couple of things.
Number one, that person is going

to help the company
brainstorm on new initiatives,
because the chief data officer will have
a good understanding of capabilities
in the world of data and in analytics.
And that information can be used
to inspire new ideas as it comes

to what business initiatives
should we be working on.
But then the second thing

that the chief data
officer would be involved
in strategy development for

is to observe the initiatives
that emerge from that process.
That way, as those initiatives emerge,

then the chief data
officer is gonna make sure

that the roadmap for
overall data strategy,

of which data governance
is a part of that,
is gonna make sure that it's revised.

And it's revised to target
whichever business initiatives
that the chief data officer feels
is appropriate to align to.
That way you're not, you know,
looking for the initiatives
that are very far down the road already
with their schedules and plans

and what their architecture
is gonna look like
in terms of data,

but instead you're catching
it at the very beginning
so that you can evolve the plans
for data right alongside the plans
for those business initiatives.

And therefore it becomes
just a natural part
of the way initiatives are born,
and then it's a natural part

of the way the data governance
process evolves over time.
So that's the strategic level.

And then through that there is
always some funding process.
We talked about making sure

that you're aligned to
funded business initiatives,

or initiatives that are
very likely to be funded.

So where is that funding
process in your organization?
Can you attach to that
and have observability into that,

where you see all of
the proposed initiatives
and projects that go through that?
And then you find the opportunity

for the data that they're
going to need to be successful.
And again, you create or refine your plans

to support those with
the right data governance

to make sure the data is
in a condition necessary.
You do not need all of the details. Okay?

A lot of times people will
say, "Well, wait a minute,

I don't know all of
their data requirements.
I don't know all of their,
you know, all the detailed data.
We haven't done the data profiling.
We don't know where the challenges are."
That's fine.

You should plan your
data governance program
at the same level of detail

as the plans there are
for those initiatives.
So for example, let's say somebody

is proposing a pricing
optimization initiative.
That's it. That's all I know.

Well, what do I know
for sure I'm gonna need?
I'm gonna need price history.
I'm gonna need to know the impact
of price history on sales
and the impact that it has.

I'm gonna need to know
information about products.
And I'm gonna need to have information,
not just about products,

but by location and
information about products

as it relates to web presence
and things like that.

And I can even have discussions
or have an understanding

of the condition of
our data to support it.

Again, going back to the
customer experience example,
I know, generally,

the condition of data across
different business units.
I may not know in detail,
and I may not have the detailed statistics

about that customer data
through profiling yet,
but I generally know if customer data
across the different customer channels
is coherent, linked, or not.
And if it isn't,

and I have an initiative
that is being proposed
and likely to be funded,
then I can put something on the roadmap

that has that scope,
it has that direction,
even if I don't have the details.
And as the requirements emerge in detail
for those targeted initiatives,

then I'm gonna detail out
the plans to support it.
So this is what I mean by making it a part

of the fabric of the
ecosystem of the organization.

And going further with this,
enterprise architecture.
So this is another opportunity.

So enterprise architecture
generally is looking
across projects to both serve them,
you know, with shared architecture

and also to contribute
to a shared architecture.
So there's sort of a two-way interplay
between the projects that leverage
and also produce elements
of the shared enterprise architecture.
So what we wanna make sure

is that the enterprise
architecture function has
an enterprise data architecture.
This is not just about,

it's not just about
standardizing on technology,

which database to use,
under which circumstances,
but it's also about ensuring
that our data resources are being deployed
in a way that are shared.
So it's not just about which database
to use for customer data,

but it's also about that
customer experience initiative
coming along and both contributing to

and leveraging a shared
customer data resource.
Again, not just because it's a good idea,
but because we have a list of initiatives
that can benefit from this process.

So enterprise data architecture
often has something

along the lines of like an
architecture review board
or something that's gonna keep a close eye
on projects as they evolve,

and it's going to, you know,
provide that oversight.
And we want to make sure that data

is a part of that
architecture review board.

Again, we're not creating
something completely separate
for data governance,
but we're piggybacking on the set
of processes that exist.
And this is another example.
And so the enterprise data architect
is typically an IT role.
So we've talked about the relationship
between IT and the business.
The enterprise data architecture role
is typically a person

in the overall IT enterprise
architecture function,
and it's not technically a direct part
of the data governance program,
but it is a linkage opportunity.

So we talked about the need
for business involvement,

and in the IT partnership
with the business,
for doing things like sharing data
and integrating data across projects.

So the enterprise data
architecture function
can have a relationship

with the data governance
program to provide,
let's call it, the political will.
The observation of the major initiatives
and the benefit that's gonna be achieved.
So it's not just a technician saying,
"Hey, you guys ought to share data."

Instead, it's a voice
of the business saying,

"Well, here are the initiatives
that are in front of us.

If we don't share data,
this one, this one,
and this one are all gonna have
to manage the same customer data over
and over and over again."
And this is real life.
This happens all the time
because individual initiatives will
in fact repeat a lot of the same work.
So you have to work out that relationship
between enterprise data architecture
and the data governance program.
And hence, by doing so,
it's an IT business partnership.
So let's go one level deeper

and into projects, into
project methodology.

So most organizations have some
kind of a standard approach
to how they deploy data in projects,
how they deploy solutions overall,

and then perhaps specifically
some set of standard tasks
and activities for deploying data.
And so now what we wanna do

is build right into the data
deployment project lifecycle,
into the methodology,

all of those data management
practices that we talked about.

So it's not just about doing
data profiling generally
or building data quality rules.
Why not put a standard task right
into the the data deployment methodology?
And what you can do there is you can say,

"Okay, here is where we
do our data profiling.

And the purpose of it
is to examine the data
for data quality issues."

And there's many other
benefits you can get
out of data profiling.
And then, typically,

in the methodology you'll have
roles and responsibilities.

So you can put the role of
the data steward directly
as a standard role for those tasks.

So you can think across
the entire lifecycle

of all of those data management
activities we talked about,
whether it's security,
you know, regulatory compliance,
data quality management,
master data management, data cataloging.
Why don't we do these things

as a standard part of
the project development?
Here is where we do profiling,

here's where we develop
our data quality rules,

here's where we catalog
our data, and so on.

And here are the roles
and responsibilities.

It doesn't mean that every
single project has to touch
on every one of those things,

but at least it's more
of an opt-out approach.

You're listing all of
the standard activities
that should at least be considered
within any data deployment process.
So you can see through this effort

that we, you know, start from
where initiatives are born.
We follow it through how they're funded

and how there's governance
already observing

and helping and interacting
with these projects.
And then the detailed responsibilities

as it relates to, and the
supporting technology,
to implement data management practices

within the scope of data
deployment projects.

This is the way we can
make data governance a part
of the fabric of the organization.
You know, and this is, again,

one of those things where I
had to discover this on my own.
I did not read about this anywhere.
And, you know, I remember in my early days
when I was, you know, first getting,
at the retailer I worked at,
we were getting our data governance

and basically our
overall data architecture

and data strategy aligned
to business initiatives
around things like supply chain management
and pricing and shelf space
and all those things that I talked about.

Well, you know, what I
realized was that I noticed
that every year everybody was asked
to propose their projects.
There were different business areas.
There were liaisons within IT

that partnered with
executives in the business,

and they would all propose their
projects for consideration.
And I just thought, well,

what a great opportunity
to look at everything
that's being proposed.
And I always used to think of,
remember the game concentration,

where you'd pick up a card
and did something like this?
I would look at all these projects
that were proposed and go,
"Oh, that one's gonna need sales data.
That one's gonna need sales data.
That one's gonna need product data.
That one's gonna need product data."

And then I would take
all these commonalities

and propose to support
them in my own projects
and work hard to make sure

that that work was not scoped
into those other projects.

So when we talk about
building a load-bearing wall,

there's no better way to
be a load-bearing wall
than to literally de-scope the work
out of those target projects,
put them into a shared project
that can serve multiple efforts.
And we did this, you know, every year,
and it got better and better.
And we also built

into the project methodology
very specific tasks and roles.
And the thing is, you know,
we didn't build them all at once.

But every time a new
capability was deployed,

we got a new data quality tool
capability or what have you,
a data catalog capability, and so on,
a standard approach when we were acquiring
and developing that capability was
to take that capability and build it
into the various elements of the process
where it made sense.
So that way it's institutionalized
as it's acquired and developed,

and then it gets better
and better over time.
